7.87.text: I'm one of these confusing millenials

9.97.text:
that's managed to making a living
through a weird hobby.

24.44.text: I learned to compose through programming

26.92.text: or hacking this, a Nintendo Gameboy

31.36.text: using a piece of homebrew software

33.89.text: called LSDJ or Little Sound DJ.

39.57.text: This allows me to treat the Gameboy

41.35.text: as if it's a very basic synthesizer.

44.30.text: So I can command it to generate a tone,

49.78.text: which I can then craft into something

53.56.text: like a kick drum or a bassline.

67.42.text: With those instruments I'd create a song.

72.28.text: That chippy sound is probably something

74.14.text:
that you remember from your childhood
or from when you were younger

77.89.text:
What you can do with it in music making
is incredibly limited

81.64.text: and yet you can create an array of signs.

99.84.text: These limitations force you to think

101.83.text:
very differently and to approach
creation in an entirely new light.

107.66.text:
As soon as I came across 
this scene, I was hooked

110.50.text:
and with only a novice knowledge 
on how to make music

113.85.text: let alone make music on a Gameboy,

116.31.text: I started to play with it

117.98.text:
see what it could do
and what I could do with it.

126.33.text: there was an entire collective of people

128.48.text: from all over the world dedicated

130.50.text: to cracking the capabilities of this tech

133.29.text:
some on Commodore 64's 
or Amiga's or Atari's.

140.65.text: to make music and digital art.

144.64.text:
They were hackers 
with a "Do It Yourself" attitude,

152.32.text: to bring 'bedroom consoles' to the stage

157.50.text: We had this ability to discover,

160.17.text: create and share in the newly

166.30.text: which was born of this concept

171.42.text:
with the rigid practices
of the Industrial Era.

178.97.text: and the prospect of a better world

183.34.text:
there came a sense that
anyone could be a hacker.

190.64.text: it's probably not too difficult to imagine

193.82.text:
the stereotypical hooded figure
maybe a cyber terrorist of some sort

198.70.text: or maybe the guy fox mask comes to mind.

201.68.text:
But it used to be that a hacker was
an expert or an enthusiast of any kind.

207.96.text: Someone who was inquisitive and passionate

211.06.text:
and found enjoyment in exploring
especially within technology.

217.91.text:
So with that description surely
any one of us could be a hacker.

222.06.text:
I mean, it's in our nature to be
inquisitive and curious.

226.12.text:
We're all curious with our technology
in one way or another

229.59.text:
because I'm sure that each and
everyone of us

232.88.text:
is guilty of sitting up
until 3 am in the morning

235.89.text:
in the depths of YouTube or
Facebook or Instagram or whatever

240.30.text: knowing that you have to be up early

242.30.text:
but hey the Internet is that gift
that just keeps giving.

246.39.text:
But before we had these 
pocket sized super computers

250.81.text:
hackers would be known to 
explore their machines,

253.79.text:
crack them open, see how they work,
what makes them tick.

257.18.text:
If they didn't have something 
that worked for them

261.87.text:
Make their own software or
build their own machines.

265.81.text:
If they hadn't, the names Steve Jobs
or Steve Wozniak

271.24.text:
We wouldn't even have personal computers,
let alone our smartphones and tablets.

277.96.text:
The first home computers were built
with the radical vision of the future

282.79.text:
that everyone should own 
a personal computer.

286.22.text:
And this spurred generations
of inquisitive creatives

293.88.text: and to repurpose them into something

295.77.text: that they were never intended to be.

297.82.text: Like me with this Gameboy, for example.

301.53.text:
This hacker activity 
was known to be joyful

304.72.text:
where overcoming problems
arised genuine curiosity

308.72.text: and led to a want for more knowledge.

312.25.text:
Solutions would be deemed 
to have hacker value

315.29.text:
if they were executed with
cleverness,

319.83.text:
And this made creativity
an essential part of meaning.

324.91.text:
Curiosity is the crocs 
of creativity afterall

328.75.text: and it's in our nature to be creative.

332.89.text: So I was blown away by this idea that

336.57.text:
you could make 
music on a Gameboy

338.24.text:
and I'm sure that some of you today
probably are as well.

341.50.text: So at 16, I got myself kitted out.

344.37.text: I dug out the old classic Gameboy

347.60.text: from the depths of the toy cupboard,

349.70.text:
dusted it off and revived it 
with some fresh batteries.

355.93.text:
and before I'd even gotten past 
the first few pages of the manual

359.56.text: I was eagerly making some noise.

362.76.text: I was determined to just make something

366.34.text: and before I knew it, I had some songs.

376.37.text:
with melodies and didn't have
much sense of rhythm

379.11.text: for it to feel like it was anything

382.71.text: they were my own little creations

385.90.text: and I was proud of that.

390.70.text: and I awaited the email from Sony Records.

397.91.text: But I didn't need a lable

399.65.text: it was the spirit of the Digital Age,

401.48.text:
I could just put them out into
the world online and hope

404.60.text:
that someone out there somewhere
might be interested in listening.

411.85.text:
Chiptune had it's own community
of visualists, artists, event promoters

418.01.text: and fans spread out all over the globe.

422.04.text: So eventually I got to travel,

424.61.text: I met incredibly talented like minded individuals

427.61.text:
and this all gave me the confidence
to actually pursue a life of music,

434.55.text: and to follow my own path.

436.69.text:
It gave me this "Do It Yourself" attitude
that really stuck with me.

441.85.text:
And approaching music composition
with these constraints

445.23.text: gave me almost a programmer's mindset.

448.27.text:
The writing process often 
provoked serendipity,

451.16.text: there would be little happy accidents

453.56.text: that would give birth to a new idea.

455.94.text:
And that kept the creative flow
forever interesting and refreshing.

461.35.text:
It was such a free means 
of self expression.

465.37.text:
There were no standards 
to be met to define its quality.

471.72.text:
It forced me to to overcome 
limitations in a creative way.

475.59.text:
And that was no doubt
an important life lesson.

478.78.text: But overall it was just fun!

483.96.text: is rooted within that hacker ethic

486.43.text:
achieving unexpected results through 
playfully cracking a constraint.

491.95.text:
Before Chiptune, a movement surfaced
in Europe in the late eightees

497.66.text:
And it was probably the very first 
computer art subculture.

503.50.text:
It started out as what would probably 
now be any parent's nightmare,

509.07.text:
with a teenage boy, alone 
in his room with a computer.

524.31.text: started to flaunt their programming skills

529.27.text:
something we're quite 
familiar with today.

531.33.text: And they'd share it with their friends

535.50.text:
Eventually these things 
called 'demos' started to appear

540.59.text: They wanted to flaunt their talent right?

543.08.text:
So they'd create these audiovisual 
presentations that had insane

547.46.text: graphics and music for the time.

550.38.text:
Sometimes they'd even talk smack
about other hacker groups

556.31.text:
like and early, but much more
innocent and creative form

559.42.text:
of the demonic YouTube
comment section.

563.09.text:
It got to the point where people
didn't even care about

568.03.text: They just wanted to see these demos,

574.37.text: team up to compete with one another

579.25.text:
where huge crowds would assemble
to watch the results.

588.91.text:
They'd compete like their 
lives depended on it,

591.56.text:
longing for that moment when
jaws hit the floor

594.07.text: and people were just absolutely blown away

598.93.text: But what was it all for?

603.29.text: Honestly, it was for the art,

605.94.text: it was for that final product.

609.78.text:
There wasn't exactly that big
prize money to be won

612.46.text:
and the parties weren't
exactly big budget.

614.98.text:
So rather than focus on 
commercial gain

617.66.text: they worked to the extremes that they did

619.84.text: because they loved doing it, it was fun!

624.12.text:
And like Chiptune, the musical 
love letter to the demo scene,

628.00.text:
this movement was dedicated
to cracking constraints

633.92.text: They were making things with computers

635.96.text:
that people did not believe
to be possible at the time.

640.20.text: And because of their desire to create

642.57.text:
some went on to form
video game companies,

649.55.text:
Something that they trained 
themselves to be.

653.48.text:
So I inadvertently became a
video game composer

664.10.text:
Without really realizing 
the scope of it

666.21.text: I had created a brand for myself

669.61.text:
Marketing was something that 
almost came naturally

672.35.text: to us who grew up with the Internet.

677.34.text:
was as simple as setting up your 
very first embarrassing email address.

682.51.text:
And growing up I was raised to 
understand the value of money

686.37.text: not as a goal in life,

687.84.text: but as a necessity for survival.

689.91.text:
To make a living doing something
that you love is the goal, right?

693.78.text: And a hacker is not naïve.

695.70.text: They understand that income is essential

698.15.text: to have that freedom to create

703.09.text: But this transition from simply playing

705.71.text:
to making a living was a complete
shock to the system for me.

711.62.text: I think as adults we start to become

719.40.text: trying to find answers to things

721.20.text:
that might not necessarily 
have a logical outcome.

724.80.text:
We can end up valuing our own 
worth through keeping score,

731.61.text:
something that is very much
the driving force in school

736.58.text:
and this competitive nature 
we're told defines success.

742.75.text:
And teen years come 
with a natural swagger.

747.28.text:
And this can give us the belief 
that anything is possible.

751.07.text:
But with an ego in the 
driving seat for too long,

754.12.text:
we can end up with this 
distorted vision of reality.

761.22.text:
and illusions, however
diminished or glorified.

765.34.text:
Where our understanding 
of our abilities

767.54.text: is not what they are right now

769.50.text:
but rather what they 
should be in the future.

772.72.text: And this can hold us back

776.48.text:
Or it can morph into
overconfidence and arrogance

780.99.text:
sometimes coupled with the
desire for fame or money,

784.68.text:
mimicking others or following
trends to find the spotlight.

788.53.text:
But arrogance brings no 
contribution to your work.

794.72.text: In fact, it has the opposite effect.

797.32.text: I'm sure that maybe we've all experienced

803.40.text:
self depreciation,
trying to keep it all together.

806.70.text:
Sometimes the Digital Era 
can just set the bar so high

811.54.text: to stop you from even trying.

818.85.text:
Our academic studies 
may tell us otherwise,

821.47.text: with such little focus on self discovery,

827.03.text:
But we've been forever 
compared to one another

833.04.text: But comparison is the thief of joy,

837.18.text:
and any creator will 
know that all too well.

840.36.text: That creative impulse is within all of us.

848.80.text:
doing what we could do 
and not what we should do.

853.58.text:
We're all eager to throw 
caution to the wind and

855.92.text:
go nuts with our imagination 
when we're kids

859.66.text:
this adult state of mind 
comes into play

where we don't believe in ourselves

I felt like I stepped into

It resonated with me on a

885.31.text:
or self taught artists,

And there was something 
incredibly beautiful about that.

905.52.text: I instantly fell in love with it.

909.41.text: And the scene had an attitude,

911.85.text: it didn't care what you thought.

914.22.text: It was playfully wild and free,

917.61.text: creatively beautiful in its own rights.

919.95.text:
Where having fun and dismissing 
standards was the focus.

924.48.text: Each one of us had taken a...

926.22.text:
had resonated with this movement
in one way or another,

929.96.text: and taken upon ourselves to join in,

932.62.text: to push the limits of our creativity.

936.07.text:
And our artistic expression 
should be about absorbing life,

941.15.text: our hopes, our aspirations, our fears,

946.80.text: There's a therapeutic value in creation.

949.15.text:
We can make sense of those emotions
through giving them an entity.

954.13.text: The limitation that we must crack

956.43.text:
is to overcome what stops us
from getting creative

962.46.text: It's the essence of the Digital Era,

965.44.text:
where hackability is to participate
instead of being a passive consumer.

971.30.text: We can invent the future that we want

973.81.text: and not the one that we're given.

976.57.text:
So instead of staying up all 
night passively consuming,

982.06.text: or the people that will help you grow.

985.26.text:
Approach creation with wonder,
determination, curiosity,

992.15.text: You'll never know what will come of it.

999.41.text:
where the goal is not 
for money or fame

1011.68.text: and take that first step into the unknown.
